DOCNAME: AJAYI AND OTHERS v. THE UNITED KINGDOM
TEXT: The first and fourth applicants were born in DATE and DATE respectively and are both NORP citizens . Their mother , the second applicant , born in DATE , is a NORP citizen . The third applicant , husband to the second applicant , father of the fourth applicant and step - father to the first applicant , is a NORP citizen , born in DATE . Since DATE the family have returned from GPE to live in GPE in PERSON .
The applicants are represented by ORG , a lawyer working for the FAC in GPE . The facts may be summarised as follows .
A.

B , the second applicant , first entered GPE on DATE having been granted leave to remain as a visitor for DATE . On DATE , B was discovered by an immigration officer to have taken up paid employment in breach of her entry requirements and she was arrested by the immigration authorities . Later that same day LAW to make a deportation order was signed . B lodged an appeal with the Adjudicator .

On DATE , B married F , the first applicant 's father , a NORP citizen whom she had known for DATE . B applied for leave to remain as a spouse and dropped her appeal against the decision to deport . B became pregnant but was forced to leave the matrimonial home due to violence inflicted on her by F , and she moved into a hostel for battered women . On DATE , the first applicant was born . On DATE , B 's application to remain on the basis of her marriage which had broken down was refused . A decree nisi dissolving the marriage was issued in DATE . F contested paternity of the first applicant but the matter was proved by DNA testing . He has retained no contact with his daughter .

On DATE , a deportation order was signed by the Secretary of ORG against B. An application to revoke the order was refused on DATE . Leave to apply for judicial review of this decision was granted and the judicial review hearing took place on CARDINAL DATE . It was held that the Secretary of ORG had failed to take into account the rights of the first applicant , a NORP citizen , when making the decision not to revoke the deportation order . The matter was remitted back to the Secretary of ORG . On DATE , by letter , the Secretary of ORG made a fresh refusal to revoke LAW of DATE . In a letter sent by ORG to B 's solicitors , received on DATE , it was stated :

" The Secretary of ORG has considered the suggested difficulties which [ the first applicant ] might face in GPE and her rights as a NORP citizen and has balanced them against her mother 's breach of the immigration control ... and remains of the view that there are insufficient grounds for revoking the deportation order . "

On DATE , B married the third applicant , a NORP citizen whom she had known for some time . The Secretary of ORG was informed of B 's marriage . In a letter dated DATE , B 's solicitors informed ORG that B was pregnant . This letter apparently crossed in the post with a letter to B 's solicitors dated DATE from ORG which stated :

" [ B 's ] marriage on DATE to a NORP citizen gives her no right to remain in GPE and the Secretary of ORG is not prepared to grant her leave to remain on this basis ... removal directions have been deferred for a period of DATE after which further steps will be taken to effect [ B 's ] removal " .

On DATE , representations were made by B 's Member of ORG ( GPE ) to the Secretary of ORG informing him of B 's pregnancy and the fact that she had developed fibroids which could lead to complications during childbirth , potentially requiring specialised medical supervision .

On DATE , the applicants ' representatives were informed by ORG that no fresh decision had been taken in the light of the information concerning B 's pregnancy . However , that same evening B was served with fresh removal directions for herself and the first applicant to travel to GPE on DATE and was informed by the immigration officers that the directions had been set in full knowledge of the pregnancy . The removal arrangements were however deferred for the Secretary of ORG to consider the representations made by B 's M.P. Shortly afterwards , in a letter dated DATE , the NORP Under Secretary of ORG informed the applicants ' GPE that since medical facilities existed in GPE for B 's condition no grounds existed to justify revoking the deportation order .

On DATE , the fourth applicant was born in GPE . On DATE , B was visited by immigration officers and DATE was served with a notice of variation of restrictions , obliging her to report to a police station on a DATE basis .

In DATE , B , the second applicant , applied for a visa to travel to GPE . While the visa application was still pending before the NORP authorities , removal directions were set by ORG for the second applicant to be returned to GPE on DATE . On DATE , following intervention by the applicants ' representatives before ORG , the removal directions were deferred to allow the second applicant to obtain the visa . The second applicant , as the wife of an ORG national , was granted a visa by the NORP authorities and in DATE all the applicants moved to GPE . For DATE , the third applicant was unsuccessful in his attempts to find employment there . The financial cost of the family 's move to GPE and the expenses incurred by the third applicant , who travelled to work in GPE DATE , left the applicants with very little disposable income . They had limited personal savings . The visa granted to the second applicant to travel to GPE provided no entitlement to social security assistance because the third applicant had failed to find employment there .
In a letter dated DATE the ORG stated in reference to the second applicant being granted a visa to travel to GPE :
" the Secretary of ORG remains of the intention to deport the second applicant to GPE should she fail to embark elsewhere " .
In or around DATE the second applicant gave birth to a third child . At some time before DATE the third applicant obtained employment in GPE at a much lower wage than he was earning in GPE .

In DATE , the applicants applied to return to GPE as , under ORG law , after spending a qualifying period in GPE they could return to GPE . The deportation order against the second applicant was revoked . On DATE , a travel visa was issued and the whole family returned to GPE at DATE . On DATE , the second applicant applied for a GPE residence permit under ORG law and a permit was issued on DATE until DATE .
B. Relevant domestic law and practice
Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the LAW DATE provides that :
“ A person who is not a NORP citizen shall be liable to deportation from GPE
( a ) if , having only a limited leave to enter or remain , he does not observe a condition attached to the leave or remains beyond the time limited by the leave ... . ”
Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the LAW provides :

“ A person who is not a NORP citizen shall be guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction with a fine ... or with imprisonment ... or with both ... ( b ) if , having only a limited leave to enter or remain in GPE , he knowingly ... ( ii ) fails to observe a condition of the leave . ”
Immigration Rules are made pursuant to ORG ) of the LAW . The Immigration Rules HC CARDINAL were applicable in the period DATE .
Paragraph CARDINAL provides :
Paragraph CARDINAL ( which is repeated in the new ORG CARDINAL in force from DATE at § CARDINAL ) states :

“ In considering whether to give effect to a recommendation for deportation ... the Secretary of ORG will take into account every relevant factor known to him , including : age ; length of residence in GPE ; strength of connections with GPE ; personal history , including character , conduct and employment record ; domestic circumstances ; the nature of the offence of which the person is convicted ; previous criminal record ; compassionate circumstances ; any representations received on the applicant ’s behalf . ”
Paragraph CARDINAL provides :

“ PERSON will normally be the proper course where the person has failed to comply with or has contravened a condition or has remained without authorisation . Full account is to be taken of all the relevant circumstances known to the Secretary of ORG including those listed in paragraph CARDINAL before a decision is reached . ”
The Secretary of ORG has issued guidance to those in his ORG who determine cases involving marriage and children . The guidance is known as GPE . LAW states :

“ As a general rule deportation action under section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(a ) or section CARDINAL(CARDINAL)(b ) ( in non criminal cases ) , or illegal entry action should not be initiated or pursued where the subject has a genuine and subsisting marriage to a person settled in GPE if :
a ) the marriage predates enforcement action ; and
b ) the marriage has lasted DATE or more or , in the case of a common law relationship ... the couple have cohabited for DATE or more ... . ”
